questions.text: Disease caused by toxin of seeds of this plant is ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Epidemic Dropsy is a form of edema (swelling) that occurs due to the consumption of adulterated mustard oil.

The condition is primarily caused by contamination of mustard oil with Argemone oil, which is extracted from the seeds of the Argemone mexicana plant. This adulteration leads to a toxic reaction in the body, resulting in the clinical features associated with epidemic dropsy.

Key Features of Epidemic Dropsy:

  1. Edema:
    • The hallmark of epidemic dropsy is bilateral pitting edema, especially in the lower limbs. This swelling is due to fluid accumulation in the tissues.
  2. Gastrointestinal Symptoms:
    • Patients may experience nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, which are common in the early stages of the disease.
  3. Cardiovascular Issues:
    • The condition can lead to serious cardiac symptoms, including palpitations, breathlessness, and in severe cases, congestive heart failure.
  4. Skin Eruptions:
    • Skin changes like erythema (redness), eruptions, and a feeling of warmth in the affected areas are also observed.
  5. Respiratory Symptoms:
    • Breathlessness and cough may develop, often related to fluid overload and heart failure.
  6. Complications:
    • If untreated, epidemic dropsy can lead to complications such as heart failure, renal failure, glaucoma, and even death.
  7. Treatment:
    • Immediate discontinuation of the contaminated oil is essential.
    • Treatment involves managing symptoms with diuretics for edema, cardiac support, and other supportive measures as needed.
  8. Prevention:
    • Prevention focuses on ensuring the purity of mustard oil, public awareness campaigns, and stringent regulation and monitoring of edible oils to prevent contamination.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Epidemic Dropsy is a form of edema (swelling) that occurs due to the consumption of adulterated mustard oil.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following Skin finding. You would advise supplementation with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows rough, dry skin suggestive of phrynoderma. It is treated by supplementation of safflower oil (rich in essential fatty acids) and vitamin B complex.

Phrynoderma or toad skin is a type of follicular hyperkeratosis. It is caused by a deficiency of vitamin E, B, A, C, and essential fatty acids.

Phrynoderma is a skin condition commonly associated with deficiency of nutrients such as essential fatty acids, vitamin A, vitamin E, and B-complex vitamins may also contribute. The condition is characterized by the development of rough, dry, and bumpy skin, particularly on the extensor surfaces like the elbows, knees, and buttocks.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Rough, dry skin suggestive of phrynoderma. It is treated by supplementation of safflower oil (rich in essential fatty acids) and vitamin B complex.

questions.text: A 12-week-old infant presents with fever, cyanosis, and fatigue. A chest X-ray is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The chest X-ray demonstrates the classic "snowman" or "figure-of-eight" sign, which is most often associated with the supracardiac type of TAPVC.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)

Pathophysiology:

  • In TAPVC, the pulmonary veins do not drain into the left atrium. Instead, they connect abnormally to the right atrium, either directly or through systemic veins.
  • TAPVC is not dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus for survival.

Common Sites of Abnormal Venous Drainage:

  • Supracardiac (most frequent): via the superior vena cava
  • Cardiac type: through the right atrium or coronary sinus
  • Infracardiac type
  • Mixed type

Clinical Presentation:

  • Cyanosis combined with signs of heart failure
  • Presence of an ASD leads to a wide, fixed split of the second heart sound

Chest X-ray Findings:

  • Supracardiac TAPVC produces the "snowman" or "figure-of-8" appearance

Management:

  • Definitive treatment is surgical repair
  • Prostaglandins are not used, since this lesion is not ductal-dependent

Explanation of other options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option B): Chest X-ray typically shows a boot-shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy.

Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA) (Option C): Characterized radiographically by an "egg-on-a-string" sign.

Pericardial Effusion (Option D): Produces a globular or "water bottle" shaped cardiac silhouette.

Key Takeaway:

In a cyanotic infant with heart failure and a chest X-ray showing a snowman/figure-8 sign, think of supracardiac TAPVC. Surgery is the treatment of choice.

Reference:

Partial and Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.text: A patient involved in a motor vehicle accident was brought to the emergency department 2 hours post-injury. He was stable, with GCS 15/15 and reactive pupils. Examination revealed bruising and tenderness over the left lower chest wall with petechiae, severe tenderness in the left hypochondrium, and blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg. What is the most appropriate investigation in the emergency room?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In trauma patients presenting with abdominal or thoracic injury suspicion, the FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is the investigation of choice in the ER.

FAST (Focused Abdominal Sonography for Trauma) and eFAST (Extended FAST)

  • Purpose: Rapid bedside ultrasound to detect free intraperitoneal, pericardial, or pleural fluid.
  • Utility: Helps quickly identify hemoperitoneum, hemothorax, or pericardial tamponade.
  • Advantages:
    • Non-invasive and portable
    • Performed simultaneously with resuscitation
    • Detects as little as ~100 mL of blood
    • Reproducible and rapid
  • Limitations:
    • Operator-dependent
    • Less reliable in obese patients or with excessive bowel gas
    • Low sensitivity for hollow viscus injury and retroperitoneal trauma
    • Cannot fully define the extent of organ damage

Explanation of other options:

X-ray (Option B): Useful for fractures or chest injuries but not reliable for intra-abdominal bleeding.

DPL (Option C): Sensitive for intraperitoneal bleeding and still used in resource-limited areas, but invasive and largely replaced by FAST/eFAST. Contraindicated in pregnancy, prior laparotomy, and obvious laparotomy cases.

CT scan (Option D): Gold standard for detailed evaluation of solid organ injury but requires a hemodynamically stable patient. Not ideal in this hypotensive patient.

Key Takeaway:

In a hemodynamically unstable trauma patient, the first-line ER investigation is FAST, as it rapidly detects intraperitoneal, pleural, or pericardial fluid and guides immediate management.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and progressive distension. An abdominal X-ray reveals multiple dilated bowel loops. Based on the radiographic findings, identify the bowel segment involved.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray demonstrates dilated small bowel loops with mucosal folds (valvulae conniventes) crossing the entire lumen, which are most characteristic of the jejunum.

  • Valvulae conniventes (plicae circulares):
    • Prominent mucosal folds running across the full width of the lumen.
    • Best appreciated in the jejunum and proximal ileum.
    • Radiographically create a "feathery" appearance on plain X-ray.

Thus, the presence of these folds confirms that the dilated loops belong to the jejunum.

Radiographic Features of Small Bowel Obstruction

  • Initial Test: Plain abdominal X-ray
    • Erect view: Shows air-fluid levels in a step-ladder pattern.
    • Supine view: Helps localize the obstruction site.
  • Gold Standard (IOC): Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT)
    • Useful for identifying high-grade obstruction, strangulation, or extraluminal causes.

Key Radiographic Differentiation

  • Jejunum:
    • Central loops, markedly dilated
    • Prominent valvulae conniventes spanning the full width
    • "Feathery" mucosal pattern
  • Ileum (Option B):
    • Central loops, dilated
    • Featureless/characterless appearance due to less distinct mucosal folds
  • Duodenum (Option C):
    • Retroperitoneal, not typically well-visualized unless massively distended
  • Transverse Colon (Option D):
    • Haustrations that appear as incomplete lines, not extending across the lumen

Key Takeaway:

On abdominal X-ray, dilated central loops with mucosal folds crossing the entire lumen (valvulae conniventes) point toward jejunal obstruction, while ileal loops look "characterless" and colonic haustrations do not span the full width.

questions.text: A 15-year-old with a known history of spinal tuberculosis presents with low-grade fever, dull aching back pain, and persistent hip flexion. Movements at the hip are painful and restricted. On CT imaging, the muscle marked as 2 is involved. Which muscle is it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure labeled 2 corresponds to the psoas muscle. In the clinical context of spinal TB with hip flexion deformity, this points toward a psoas abscess, a common complication of Pott's disease.

  • Iliopsoas muscle function:
    • Formed by psoas major and iliacus
    • Chief flexor of the hip joint
    • When inflamed, spasm pulls the femur anteriorly, leading to persistent hip flexion
  • Psoas abscess in spinal TB:
    • Caused by spread of infection from vertebral bodies into the psoas compartment
    • Presents with fever, back pain, limp, and hip flexion deformity

Spinal Tuberculosis (Pott's Disease)

  • Common sites:
    • Adults → lower thoracic and upper lumbar vertebrae
    • Children → upper thoracic vertebrae
  • Pathology:
    • Granulomatous infection spreads to adjacent vertebrae and intervertebral discs
    • Vertebral collapse → kyphotic deformity (gibbus)
    • Cold abscess formation:
      • Upper spine → may extend to chest wall
      • Lower spine → may track along psoas, presenting as psoas abscess
  • Diagnosis:
    • Imaging (CT/MRI): Demonstrates vertebral destruction, abscesses
    • Definitive confirmation: Biopsy/aspiration with culture or histology
  • Complications:
    • Paraplegia due to cord compression or large abscess → may need urgent drainage

Explanation of other options:

1 (Option A): Abdominal wall muscles (rectus abdominis, external/internal oblique, transversus abdominis), provide trunk stability and movement, not associated with hip flexion deformity in spinal TB.

3 (Option C): Adductor muscles (longus, brevis, magnus), located in medial thigh, function is hip adduction, not implicated in this presentation.

4 (Option D): Gluteal muscles (maximus, medius, minimus), function in hip extension, abduction, and rotation; not related to psoas abscess formation.

Key Takeaway

In spinal tuberculosis, a cold abscess may track into the psoas muscle, producing hip flexion deformity due to iliopsoas spasm.

Reference:

  1. Tuberculosis of the spine - PMC.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality shown in the figure below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image corresponds to a PET-CT scan, a hybrid imaging technique that merges positron emission tomography (PET) with computed tomography (CT).

  • PET component: Detects metabolic activity using a positron-emitting tracer such as F-18 fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG). Areas with increased glucose uptake (e.g., tumors, active inflammation) appear as "hot spots."
  • CT component: Provides high-resolution anatomical detail.
  • Combined advantage: Functional (metabolic) information from PET is fused with anatomical localization from CT, greatly improving diagnostic accuracy.

PET vs SPECT

Explanation of other options:

Cerebral blood flow scan (Option A): A type of SPECT imaging used for brain perfusion studies, not PET-CT.

Sestamibi scan (Option C): Uses Tc-99m sestamibi with a gamma camera, commonly performed for cardiac perfusion, parathyroid adenomas, and breast lesions.

Full body MDCT (Option D): Purely anatomical imaging using multi-detector CT, excellent for structural abnormalities but lacks metabolic information.

Key Takeaway:

PET-CT uniquely combines functional imaging (metabolism) with structural detail (anatomy), making it the gold standard in oncology for tumor detection, staging, and monitoring response to therapy.

Reference:

https://www.nibib.nih.gov/science-education/science-topics/nuclear-medicine#

questions.text:
After a road traffic accident, a patient arrives at the emergency department. On examination, he is awake and alert, with:
1. BP: 90/60 mmHg
2. Respiratory rate: 40/min
3. Pulse: 120 bpm
An X-ray is provided showing pathology. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The chest X-ray demonstrates a right-sided pneumothorax. Given the patient’s tachypnea, tachycardia, and borderline hypotension, immediate decompression is required.

  • Definitive management: Insertion of an intercostal chest tube (tube thoracostomy) to evacuate air and allow lung re-expansion.
  • This restores normal pleural pressure, improves ventilation, and stabilizes hemodynamics.

Radiographic Features of Pneumothorax

  • Radiolucent (black) area without lung markings
  • Lung edge seen as a thin sharp radiopaque line, retracted toward the hilum
  • In tension pneumothorax:
    • Mediastinal shift to the opposite side
    • Depression of ipsilateral diaphragm
    • Collapsed lung on affected side

Special views to detect small pneumothorax:

  • Expiratory film: Enhances visibility as lung volume decreases
  • Lateral decubitus view (affected side up): Helps detect small pleural air
  • Supine patients: A horizontal beam lateral film may reveal anterior pneumothorax
  • Investigation of choice (IOC): CT chest - highly sensitive for small or loculated pneumothoraces.

Explanation of other options:

Pericardiocentesis (Option B): Indicated for pericardial tamponade, not pneumothorax.

Thoracotomy (Option C): Reserved for massive hemothorax, uncontrolled bleeding, or persistent large air leaks, not the first-line treatment here.

Pleurodesis (Option D): Elective procedure for recurrent pneumothorax, not in an acute traumatic case.

Key Takeaway:

In a trauma patient with pneumothorax on chest X-ray, the next step is chest tube insertion to decompress the pleural cavity and allow lung expansion.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441885/

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7390330/

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with bone pain and abdominal cramps, and her family mentions a history of unusual behaviour. Based on these clinical features, the doctor suspects a diagnosis. Which investigation would be the most suitable to confirm it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features of bone pain due to excessive bone resorption, abdominal discomfort from elevated calcium levels, and neuropsychiatric manifestations such as behavioural changes point toward primary hyperparathyroidism, for which the preferred imaging modality is a sestamibi scan.

Explanation of other options:

MRI (Option A): Although MRI can detect soft tissue lesions, it is not the preferred initial imaging technique for identifying parathyroid adenomas, as it is costlier, takes longer, and provides no clear benefit compared to sestamibi scanning in parathyroid evaluation.

Ultrasonogram (Option B): Ultrasound can help visualise parathyroid enlargement, but its accuracy is limited by operator skill and difficulty in detecting ectopic glands. It is often used as an adjunctive test rather than the most reliable first-line diagnostic method.

CT scan (Option D): CT scan offers precise anatomical detail but does not provide the functional assessment available with sestamibi scans. Although helpful in preoperative planning, it is not considered the primary imaging method for diagnosing parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of hematuria and recurrent urinary tract infection. You notice the following finding in his CT. What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient, presenting with blood in the urine and recurrent urinary tract infections, was diagnosed with Horseshoe Kidney. CT imaging of the abdomen demonstrated fusion of the kidneys at their lower poles, creating a U-shaped configuration.

Horseshoe Kidney

Definition:

  • A congenital renal anomaly where the lower poles of both kidneys fuse, creating a U-shaped configuration.

Cause & Pathogenesis:

  • Fusion occurs during fetal development at the lower poles.
  • The inferior mesenteric artery obstructs the normal ascent of the fused isthmus, leaving the kidney positioned lower in the abdomen.

Clinical Features:

  • Often asymptomatic.
  • Possible symptoms:
    • Flank or abdominal pain (due to obstruction or renal calculi).
    • Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
    • Hydronephrosis.
    • Hematuria.
    • Rovsing's Syndrome: hyperextension of the spine leading to nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.

Investigations:

  • CT Angiography (Investigation of Choice): Provides detailed assessment of renal anatomy, abnormal vasculature, and complications. CT Abdomen showing Horseshoe kidney
  • CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): Alternative when CT angio unavailable.
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP): Characteristic findings include:
    • Medial orientation of calyces ("Hand Joining Sign").
    • High ureteral insertion with anterior displacement ("Flower Vase Sign").

Management:

  • Asymptomatic Cases: Observation with periodic monitoring.
  • Symptomatic Cases:
    • Ureteropelvic Junction (UPJ) Obstruction: Surgical correction (e.g., pyeloplasty).
    • Renal Calculi: Hydration, medical therapy, or surgical stone removal.
    • Recurrent UTIs: Antibiotic therapy and preventive strategies.
  • Isthmus Consideration: Avoid surgical division since it contains functioning renal tissue.
  • Pregnancy: May cause dystocia due to altered renal position.

Polycystic kidney disease (Option A) is an inherited disorder characterised by the presence of multiple fluid-filled cysts that progressively enlarge the kidneys. On CT imaging, the condition typically appears as numerous round or oval cysts without evidence of renal fusion. In contrast, the presented CT findings demonstrate fused kidneys, which rules out PKD as the diagnosis.


Hydronephrosis (Option C) results from obstruction in the urinary tract, leading to dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces with swelling of the kidney. On CT imaging, it is identified by fluid-filled dilated collecting systems, but the kidneys remain separate and are not fused. In contrast, the CT scan in this case shows fused kidneys at the lower poles, consistent with a horseshoe kidney rather than hydronephrosis.


Pancake kidney (Option D) is an uncommon congenital malformation in which both kidneys are completely fused, forming a compact, flattened disc-shaped structure. On CT imaging, it presents as a low-lying, flat renal mass in the pelvis or lower abdomen. In contrast, the current case demonstrates a U-shaped fusion at the lower poles, consistent with a horseshoe kidney rather than a pancake kidney.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance
Vomiting is a late adverse reaction
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
All the adverse effects are reversible

questions.text: What statement accurately describes radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The inverse square law explains that the intensity of radiation falls in proportion to the square of the distance from the source. In radiotherapy, this principle is crucial for delivering the prescribed dose to the target while limiting exposure to nearby normal tissues.

Vomiting as a late adverse effect (Option B): Incorrect. Vomiting is considered an early or acute reaction, commonly occurring shortly after radiotherapy, especially when the treatment involves the brain, abdomen, or systemic irradiation.

Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant (Option C): Incorrect. In fact, cells that divide quickly-such as malignant cells, bone marrow precursors, and gastrointestinal epithelium-are highly radiosensitive. Their vulnerability arises because radiation is most effective during active phases of the cell cycle.

All adverse effects are reversible (Option D): Incorrect. Although certain effects, such as fatigue and skin erythema, may resolve, others-including tissue fibrosis and necrosis-are irreversible and may persist long-term.

Reference:

The Relationship Between Travel Distance for Treatment and Outcomes in Patients Undergoing Radiation Therapy: A Systematic Review - PMC

questions.text: Identify the rib that is shown in the X-ray
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The rib that is shown in the X-ray is the posterior part of the 3rd rib.

3rd rib - posterior part: The posterior portion of the 3rd rib is identified based on its proximity to the vertebrae and its relatively horizontal orientation, which is more evident on a lateral X-ray view. On imaging, this part of the rib lies closer to the spine and appears more curved and parallel to the vertebral column. The highlighted structure in the image matches these features, confirming it as the posterior part of the 3rd rib.

3rd rib, anterior part (Option A): This lies closer to the sternum and slopes downward and forward on X-ray. The structure shown does not match this orientation.

4th rib, anterior part (Option C): The 4th rib lies lower than the 3rd, and its anterior end is also closer to the sternum. The highlighted rib does not fit this anatomical position.

1st rib, anterior part (Option D): Located superiorly near the clavicle, its anterior portion lies close to the sternum. This does not correspond to the rib visualised in the image.

Reference: Rib radiographs for trauma: useful or wasteful? - PubMed

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a neonate presenting with frothing from the mouth and respiratory distress, with the X-ray provided below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical manifestations indicate esophageal atresia with tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF). The diagnosis is supported by the characteristic presentation of frothiness from the mouth and respiratory distress, along with the pathognomonic X-ray finding of a coiled tube in the upper esophagus.

This condition results from disrupted embryonic development of the trachea and esophagus.

TEF commonly presents with frothing and bubbling at the mouth and nose, coughing, cyanosis, and respiratory distress that worsens with feeding. The condition is often associated with VACTERL anomalies.

Transient tachypnea of newborn (Option A) presents with mild respiratory distress that improves within 24-72 hours after birth. The X-ray shows normally inflated or hyperinflated lungs with streaky perihilar markings and a shaggy heart border with clear lung periphery. This condition is self-limiting and typically resolves spontaneously.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (Option B) demonstrates characteristic X-ray findings of cyst-like structures (bowel loops) in the left hemithorax with mediastinal shift to the right and a relatively gasless abdomen. This condition results from a developmental defect in the diaphragm allowing abdominal contents to enter the thoracic cavity.

Respiratory distress syndrome (Option D) typically affects premature infants and develops within 24 hours of birth. The X-ray shows hypoaeration with bilateral fine granular opacities and prominent air bronchograms. This condition is caused by surfactant deficiency and primarily affects premature infants.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560848/

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with difficulty breathing and speech. Based on the X-ray findings, which treatment option would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture of a 2-year-old presenting with breathing and speech difficulty, along with the X-ray findings, strongly suggests a foreign body lodged in the esophagus. The most appropriate management is esophagoscopy, which allows direct visualization and removal of the foreign body.

This intervention relieves the obstruction and resolves the associated respiratory symptoms.

Typical clinical signs of an esophageal foreign body include:

  • Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)
  • Drooling of saliva
  • Respiratory distress due to compression of the airway

Importance of esophageal constrictions in esophagoscopy
Safe passage of the scope requires awareness of natural narrowings in the esophagus, which occur at four levels:

Laryngoscopy (Option A): Used for examining the larynx and upper airway. Suitable if a foreign body is suspected in the airway, not in the esophagus.

Oxygen therapy (Option C): Provides temporary relief if airway compromise is present, but it does not remove the underlying obstruction.

Tracheostomy (Option D): Indicated in life-threatening airway obstruction (e.g., laryngeal trauma, edema). Not the primary management for an esophageal foreign body.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe chest pain that he describes as "tearing" and radiating to his back. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest is taken and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's sudden, severe chest pain with a characteristic "tearing" quality radiating to the back, along with CT findings of an intimal flap dividing the aortic lumen into true and false channels, is classic for aortic dissection.

Aortic Dissection:

  • Aortic dissection involves a tear in the inner layer of the aortic wall, allowing blood to enter and split the layers of the aorta, forming a false lumen.
  • Clinical features:
    • Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region
    • Abdominal pain
    • Paraplegia
    • Syncope
    • Weakness
    • Hypotension or shock
  • Investigations:
    • CT angiography: Preferred for stable patients due to high sensitivity and availability.
    • Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): Useful in unstable patients (e.g., hypotension with SBP <100 mmHg) or when CT is inconclusive, as it can be performed at the bedside.
    • MRI: Reserved for cases where CT findings are equivocal, though less practical in acute settings.
    • Chest X-ray: May show mediastinal widening (non-specific) or pleural effusion, but these are not diagnostic.
  • Signs of False Lumen:
    • Cobweb Sign: Linear structures within the false lumen.
    • Beak Sign: Sharp angle between the intimal flap and outer aortic wall, pointing toward the false lumen.

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary embolism (Option A): Typically presents with pleuritic chest pain, shortness of breath, and shows filling defects in pulmonary arteries on CT pulmonary angiogram, not an intimal flap in the aorta.

Aortic aneurysm (Option C): Refers to a focal dilation of the aorta; unless ruptured, it is often asymptomatic. It lacks the flap and double-lumen appearance seen in dissection.

Myocardial infarction (Option D): Presents with pressure-like chest pain, often with ECG changes and elevated cardiac enzymes. CT angiography can show coronary artery occlusion or wall motion abnormalities in MI, though it's not the primary diagnostic modality.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is evaluated for repeated episodes of urinary tract infections and occasional difficulty in passing urine. As part of the diagnostic workup, an intravenous pyelogram (IVP) is conducted, and the resulting image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the radiographic findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image displays a characteristic "cobra head" appearance, which is pathognomonic for a ureterocele on IVP. This finding represents a congenital ballooning of the distal ureter at its junction with the bladder. The appearance is described as a contrast-filled outpouching within the bladder, surrounded by a thin radiolucent border corresponding to the wall of the ureterocele.

Ureterocele:

  • A congenital saccular enlargement of the terminal ureter
  • Epidemiology: Frequently observed in the pediatric population
  • Classification:
    • Intravesical (orthotopic): Entirely located within the bladder
    • Ectopic: May extend beyond the bladder and often occurs with a duplicated collecting system
  • Symptoms: Include urinary tract infections, hematuria, signs of bladder outlet obstruction, or trouble urinating
  • Imaging & Diagnosis: Most accurately diagnosed by IVP, ultrasound, or a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG)
  • Ureterocele on IVP:

Explanation of other options:

Horseshoe kidney (Option A): Involves the fusion of the lower poles of both kidneys, often associated with abnormal renal rotation. Does not present as a cystic lesion within the bladder.

Bladder tumor (Option C): Typically presents as an irregular or lobulated filling defect on imaging rather than a smooth, contrast-filled round structure.

Posterior urethral valve (Option D): Usually affects male infants and is seen on USG as a dilated posterior urethra with the "keyhole sign." It does not produce a cobra head configuration.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease. An upright chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be the cause of this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The identification of air beneath the diaphragm on upright chest or abdominal radiographs is a key sign of pneumoperitoneum, which generally arises due to perforation of a hollow gastrointestinal organ.
  • Although various causes can lead to this appearance, acute intestinal obstruction does not typically cause free intraperitoneal air unless there is progression to bowel necrosis and perforation, a complication rather than a routine manifestation of obstruction.

Free Air Under the Diaphragm (Pneumoperitoneum):

  • Free intraperitoneal air under the diaphragm suggests the escape of gas from the gastrointestinal tract into the peritoneal space, usually due to a perforated viscus. This finding is best visualized on upright imaging or CT scan.
  • Common causes include:
    • Duodenal ulcer perforation: When a peptic ulcer erodes through the wall of the stomach or duodenum, gas escapes into the peritoneal cavity, leading to pneumoperitoneum. (Option A)
    • Post-laparoscopy: Laparoscopic surgeries utilize carbon dioxide to inflate the abdominal cavity. This gas may persist postoperatively and present temporarily as free subdiaphragmatic air. (Option B)
    • Chilaiditi syndrome:This rare anatomical variant features interposition of the colon between the liver and the diaphragm, simulating free air. However, this is not due to a perforation. (Option C)

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing solid foods over the past few months. A barium swallow study is performed, and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of progressive dysphagia, along with systemic features like unintentional weight loss and reduced appetite, in conjunction with irregular stricturing and mucosal irregularity on the barium study, is highly indicative of esophageal carcinoma.

Explanation of other options:

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option B):Radiographically demonstrates a "corkscrew" or "rosary bead" pattern from non-coordinated contractions.

Esophageal leiomyoma (Option C): Presents as a smooth, intramural, well-defined filling defect on imaging, representing a benign tumor of smooth muscle origin.

Esophageal web (Option D): Typically shows as a thin shelf-like projection into the lumen, usually in the upper esophagus, frequently associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Reference:

Esophageal carcinoma

Achalasia

Bird beak sign (esophagus)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with high blood pressure, chest discomfort, and intermittent leg cramps during exertion. A chest X-ray is obtained and is shown below. Based on the radiographic evidence, what is the most likely cause of her hypertension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key radiologic features, such as the "Figure of 3" sign and rib notching, in conjunction with clinical symptoms of hypertension and exertional chest pain, strongly point to coarctation of the aorta as the underlying diagnosis.

Figure of 3 Sign:

  • A distinctive radiologic contour of the aorta resembling the number "3," frequently seen in cases of aortic coarctation.
  • This appearance results from pre-stenotic dilation, indentation at the coarctation site, and post-stenotic dilation.

Rib Notching Variants:

  • Bilateral: Seen when coarctation occurs distal to both subclavian arteries.
  • Right-sided only: When narrowing is located between the brachiocephalic trunk and left subclavian artery, or with a right-sided aortic arch.
  • Left-sided only: Suggests an aberrant right subclavian artery arising beyond the coarctation with collaterals forming on the left.

Explanation of other options:

Essential hypertension (Option B) refers to high blood pressure without any clear secondary cause and is usually diagnosed after ruling out specific etiologies. Given the abnormal X-ray findings in this patient, a secondary cause is evident.

Aortic aneurysm (Option C)present radiographically as localized widening or ballooning of the aorta, not as rib notching or Figure 3 sign.

Aorta-arteritis (Option D) seen in conditions like Takayasu arteritis, which may lead to vessel wall thickening and stenosis. However, it lacks the classic rib notching or Figure of 3 sign noted in coarctation.

Reference: Coarctation of the aorta | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

questions.text: A patient presents with severe headache and neck stiffness. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain is obtained and is shown below. Based on this imaging finding, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The CT scan reveals hyperdense areas within the subarachnoid cisterns, which is a classic sign of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). This condition involves bleeding into the subarachnoid space, typically following a ruptured cerebral aneurysm or as a result of head trauma.

Explanation of other options:

Meningitis (Option A): Although symptoms like headache and neck rigidity overlap, meningitis does not produce blood in the subarachnoid space. Imaging may reveal leptomeningeal enhancement on contrast studies.

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage (Option C): Blood in this condition is located within brain tissue rather than the subarachnoid space. Causes include hypertension or trauma.

Hemorrhagic stroke (Option D): While this term encompasses various forms of bleeding (including SAH), the specific CT finding of blood within the cisterns is most characteristic of subarachnoid hemorrhage, making it the more precise diagnosis.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470242/

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with chronic abdominal pain and complaints of intermittent fever and weight loss. Urinalysis reveals sterile pyuria. A plain abdominal X-ray is taken and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Explanation of correct answer:

The combination of clinical symptoms (chronic pain, fever, weight loss), sterile pyuria, and radiographic findings points strongly toward putty kidney, a hallmark of end-stage renal tuberculosis. This condition is characterized by a shrunken, non-functioning kidney that undergoes dystrophic calcification due to chronic TB damage.




Reference: Putty Kidney

choices.text: Saccular aneurysm of the distal arch
Dissecting aneurysm of the arch of the aorta

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with dull, persistent chest pain and progressive hoarseness of voice for the past month. He is a chronic smoker and has a history of untreated hypertension. On auscultation, no significant murmurs are noted. Based on the radiographic image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The co-existence of chest discomfort and voice hoarseness points toward Ortner's syndrome (cardiovocal syndrome), which occurs due to compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve by a thoracic vascular lesion like an aortic aneurysm.
  • The radiograph shows a focal dilation along the aortic arch, which aligns with a saccular aneurysm rather than a dissecting or narrowed segment.

Explanation of other options:

Dissecting aneurysm of the arch of the aorta (Option B): These cases generally present with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain that may radiate to the back. Imaging usually shows a double lumen or an intimal flap, not a focal bulge.

Coarctation of the aorta (Option C): Typically diagnosed in younger individuals, it presents with upper limb hypertension, weak femoral pulses, and rib notching from collateral circulation. Imaging shows luminal narrowing, not an outpouching.

Stenosis of the aorta (Option D): Refers to narrowing of the aortic valve, not the arch. It presents with syncope, angina, and exertional dyspnea, not compressive symptoms or focal aortic changes on imaging.

questions.text: A 6-week-old male infant is brought to the emergency department with a 5-day history of progressive, projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. Based on the radiograph provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The radiograph reveals features of a thickened and elongated pyloric muscle, aligning with the diagnosis of CHPS. This condition leads to gastric outlet obstruction and typically presents in male infants aged 2-6 weeks.

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms: Repeated projectile, non-bilious vomiting following feeding.
    • Physical Examination: A palpable olive-shaped mass in the epigastric region and visible gastric peristalsis may be observed.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Ultrasound (preferred modality):
      • Muscle thickness >3 mm
      • Channel length >14 mm
      • Elongated pyloric canal seen measuring 10-14 mm
    • Upper GI contrast study (alternative tool):
      • Useful for classic signs of CHPS and delayed gastric emptying.

Explanation of other options:

Annular pancreas (Option A): Though it also causes non-bilious vomiting, it is frequently associated with Down syndrome and may coexist with duodenal atresia, findings not supported by the given radiograph.

Duodenal atresia (Option C): Typically presents with bilious vomiting and a double bubble sign on imaging, which is not seen here.

Meckel's diverticulum (Option D): Most often leads to painless lower GI bleeding, rather than vomiting.

questions.text: A patient involved in a motor vehicle accident presents with back pain. Imaging is done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A Chance fracture is characteristically linked with seatbelt-type injuries and arises from a flexion-distraction mechanism. This pattern of injury typically involves disruption of the posterior spinal elements, such as spinous processes, facet joints, or the posterior ligaments, and often coexists with intra-abdominal trauma.
  • Radiographically, this fracture is recognized by a horizontal fracture line passing through the vertebral structures posteriorly, often involving both bony and ligamentous components.

Explanation of other options:

Compression Fracture (Option A): Involves the anterior portion of the vertebral body collapsing, producing a wedge-shaped vertebra, but the posterior height remains intact.


Burst Fracture (Option B): Caused by axial loading, this injury leads to the vertebral body breaking into multiple fragments, which may be displaced into the spinal canal, increasing the risk of neurologic injury.


Impacted fracture (Option D): Seen when bone fragments are driven into one another, producing increased density at the fracture site. A typical example includes impacted femoral neck fractures, rather than spinal injuries.

questions.text: A trauma patient undergoes a FAST scan. The ultrasound image is shown below. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A positive FAST scan indicates the presence of free intraperitoneal fluid, which most commonly represents hemoperitoneum in trauma patients.
  • This is typically visualized as anechoic (black) areas, especially in Morison's pouch (the hepatorenal recess), one of the first locations where fluid accumulates in the supine position.
  • This sonographic finding is significant because it suggests internal bleeding, frequently seen in blunt abdominal trauma cases.

Explanation of other options:

Negative FAST (Option B): Implies a normal study, with no evidence of free fluid or organ injury. It does not support active intra-abdominal hemorrhage.

Equivocal FAST (Option C): Describes findings that are uncertain or borderline, necessitating additional imaging, such as a CT scan, to make a definitive diagnosis.

Pneumoperitoneum (Option D): Refers to free air in the peritoneal cavity, often from visceral perforation. While ultrasound can sometimes detect free air, it is not the primary modality for identifying pneumoperitoneum; FAST is primarily used to assess free fluid (not gas).

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents with new-onset seizures. MRI shows multiple cystic brain lesions, one with a central dot (scolex). MR spectroscopy reveals elevated choline, alanine, and lactate peaks. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and imaging findings point strongly to neurocysticercosis (NCC), a parasitic infection of the CNS caused by Taenia solium. The presence of cystic brain lesions, especially one featuring a scolex, is characteristic. Additionally, the MR spectroscopy findings of increased choline, elevated alanine, and raised lactate support this diagnosis.

Neurocysticercosis:

  • Etiology: Infection with the larval stage of Taenia solium
  • Common Symptoms: Seizures, headaches, or focal neurological deficits
  • Stages: Vesicular, Colloidal, Granular, and Nodular-calcified
  • Key Radiologic and Spectroscopic Features:
  • Treatment: Albendazole + Steroids ± Antiepileptics

Explanation of other options:

Cerebral toxoplasmosis (Option A): Typically lacks the scolex sign and presents differently on spectroscopy, with lipid peaks rather than elevated alanine.

Cryptococcosis (Option C): Usually shows gelatinous pseudocysts, particularly in the basal ganglia, and MR spectroscopy shows low choline and high lipid, not alanine.

Multiple tuberculomas (Option D): Generally appear as solid granulomatous ring-enhancing lesions and tend to restrict diffusion, which differs from the cystic appearance and spectroscopic findings in NCC.

Reference:

  1. CNS cryptococcosis
  2. Intracranial Tuberculous Granuloma
  3. Neurotoxoplasmosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from an endemic region presents with vague upper abdominal discomfort. A non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hydatid cyst, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, often presents with characteristic findings on imaging, especially in later or inactive stages.
  • Non-contrast CT scans may demonstrate peripheral or complete calcification of the cyst wall, a hallmark of chronic or inactive hydatid infection.
  • Key imaging signs of hepatic hydatid cysts include:
    • Well-defined round or oval lesions
    • Peripheral or curvilinear calcifications
    • Specific patterns such as the "water-lily sign" or daughter cysts, which are more readily visible on ultrasound or MRI
  • This condition is endemic in several parts of the world, and diagnosis is strongly supported by both clinical history and imaging.

WHO Classification of Hydatid Cysts (Cystic Echinococcosis):

  • This staging system is based on ultrasound appearances, aiding diagnosis and therapeutic decision-making.

Imaging:

  • Ultrasound: First-line tool for assessing hydatid disease; best for visualizing daughter cysts, membranes, and internal contents.
  • CT and MRI: Useful for identifying calcification, complications like rupture or infection, and for pre-surgical planning.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option A): Typically shows hypervascular lesions on contrast studies; calcification is rare and not a defining feature.

Fibronodular hyperplasia (Option B): A benign liver lesion usually diagnosed via MRI with central scar; it lacks calcifications or cystic changes.

Liver abscess (Option C): Usually presents as a fluid collection with surrounding inflammation; calcification is not a common feature and the clinical presentation is often more acute.

Reference:

Hydatid cysts - WHO classification

Gharbi

questions.text:
Which of the following are typical high-resolution CT (HRCT) findings in a patient with fungal pneumonia, such as invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
1. Interlobular septations
2. Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation
3. Pleural effusion
4. Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Interlobular septations (1): Seen in some cases of invasive fungal infections such as aspergillosis and mucormycosis, where inflammation or edema leads to thickened septa on HRCT.
  • Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation (2): This appearance is highly suggestive of angioinvasive fungal infections, where vascular occlusion leads to infarction and peripheral lung consolidation in a wedge shape.
  • Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities (4): A key imaging sign in invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, the "halo sign" consists of a cavitating nodule surrounded by hemorrhagic ground-glass opacity. This reflects central necrosis surrounded by hemorrhagic infiltration.
  • Pleural effusion (3): is not typically seen in fungal pneumonias. It is more characteristic of bacterial infections or empyema, making it an uncommon feature in cases like invasive aspergillosis.

Reference:

  1. Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. Reversed Halo or Atoll Sign and Bird's Nest Sign (Vogelnest)

questions.text: A young child presents to the emergency department with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray is obtained. What is the most likely object?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Button batteries are a critical emergency when aspirated or ingested by children due to the risk of rapid tissue damage.
  • On chest X-ray, they can be identified by a distinct double ring or halo sign, caused by the metallic outer rim and inner core.
  • They pose a high risk of complications, such as mucosal erosion, chemical burns, and potential perforation, making immediate identification and removal crucial.

Radiological Features of Foreign Body Ingestion


Explanation of other options:

Coin (Option B): While coins can appear as round opacities on X-rays, they lack the characteristic double ring sign seen with button batteries. Though they may obstruct the airway or esophagus, they are generally less dangerous than batteries.

Ball (Option C): Small balls may be aspirated, but their X-ray appearance is not specific and doesn't resemble the layered look of a button battery. They don't pose the same risk of chemical damage.

Bottle cap (Option D): Although it can also cause airway obstruction, a bottle cap does not produce the double contour appearance typical of button batteries and is not associated with caustic injury.

Reference:

  1. Radiopaedia - Button Battery Oesophageal Impaction
  2. Esophageal foreign body - coin
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470298/

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with episodes of colicky abdominal pain and vomiting. An abdominal ultrasound is taken and is shown below. Which of the following radiological signs is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The target sign (also called the "doughnut sign") is a hallmark ultrasound finding, characterized by concentric echogenic and hypoechoic rings. These rings reflect layers of the bowel involved in the pathology and are especially seen in cases of intussusception or, in some instances, small bowel ischemia.
  • On imaging, this appears as circular ring-like structures that result from telescoping of the bowel layers, indicative of intussusception

Intussusception:

  • A segment of bowel telescopes into a distal segment, often leading to obstruction and reduced blood supply.
  • It is a leading cause of acute abdomen in children under 5, while adult cases are typically secondary to an underlying lesion.
  • Clinical signs in children may include intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, a palpable abdominal mass (often sausage-shaped), and currant jelly stools (from mucosal bleeding and sloughing).
  • However, less than 20% present with all classical signs, and around 15% may not experience pain.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • Plain X-ray:
      • May show a soft tissue mass in the upper right quadrant.
      • Findings of obstruction like air-fluid levels, and absence of distal bowel gas.
    • Fluoroscopy:
      • Contrast enema is diagnostic and therapeutic.
      • Shows the classic "coiled spring" appearance

    • Ultrasound:
      • Most sensitive and preferred modality.
      • Target sign: Concentric alternating echogenic (submucosa/serosa) and hypoechoic (muscularis) rings.
      • Pseudokidney sign: Longitudinal view mimicking renal architecture.
      • Crescent-in-doughnut sign.
      • Absent blood flow in Doppler indicates ischemia: contraindication for enema.
      • Ileocolic intussusception features: larger AP diameter, thickened wall, hyperechoic core, and visible lymph nodes.
    • CT Scan:
      • Displays a "bowel-within-bowel" pattern
      • Axial views: ring-like; longitudinal views: sausage-shaped.
      • May reveal a lead point and associated mesenteric structures.

Explanation of other options:

Claw sign (option A): Although associated with intussusception, it's typically observed on barium or CT studies and refers to the curved edge of the receiving bowel enveloping the intussusceptum-not the concentric ring appearance seen in ultrasound.


Claw Sign

Coffee bean sign (option C): Seen in sigmoid volvulus; the dilated sigmoid colon loops resemble a coffee bean on imaging, not applicable in this case.


Coffee Bean Sign

Lead pipe sign (option D): Seen in chronic ulcerative colitis, where the colon loses its haustral markings, giving a smooth "lead-pipe" appearance on barium enema-not a feature of intussusception.


Lead Pipe Sign

Reference:

Intussusception

questions.text: A young male presents to the emergency department following head trauma. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is taken and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An epidural hemorrhage appears on CT imaging as a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense area that lies between the skull and the dura mater.
  • It commonly results from the rupture of the middle meningeal artery, often following trauma.
  • Important features visible on imaging include mass effect, midline shift, and sharp margins.
  • Clinically, patients may exhibit a classic lucid interval, a brief recovery of consciousness followed by rapid neurological decline if not treated promptly.

Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH) and Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH)



Explanation of other options:

Intraventricular bleed (option A): This type of hemorrhage involves bleeding into the ventricular system, seen as hyperdense areas filling the ventricles, not lens-shaped. It is not typical of a post-traumatic epidural bleed.

Subdural hemorrhage (option C): Presents as a crescentic hyperdensity, located between the dura and arachnoid mater. It has a broader and more diffuse appearance compared to the sharply defined lentiform shape of an epidural bleed.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (option D): This bleed appears in the subarachnoid space, such as the basal cisterns, sulci, or ventricles. It often results from aneurysmal rupture and shows more diffuse blood spread on imaging.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470242/

questions.text: A patient presents with acute shortness of breath and orthopnea. Chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The chest X-ray demonstrates bilateral diffuse alveolar shadowing, a hallmark feature of pulmonary edema.
  • A "bat-wing" or "butterfly" distribution of opacities radiating from the hilum with peripheral sparing is commonly observed.
  • Engorged pulmonary vasculature and Kerley B lines (horizontal septal lines) often accompany these findings.
  • In cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, an enlarged heart silhouette may be evident, indicating underlying heart failure.

Pulmonary Edema:


X Ray findings of Cardiogenic pulmonary edema:


Chest X-ray showing Batwing appearance due to Alveolar edema


Chest X-ray showing Kerley B lines, Cardiomegaly, Dilated vessels of upper lobe and mild pleural effusion.

Explanation of other options:

Hydrothorax (Option B): This refers to accumulation of serous fluid in the pleural cavity (e.g., due to CHF or cirrhosis). It presents on imaging with a meniscus-shaped opacity and blunting of the costophrenic angle, not diffuse alveolar opacities.

Pleural Effusion (Option C): Typically visualized as a uniform dense opacity with a curved upper border (meniscus sign), not central bilateral alveolar infiltrates as seen in pulmonary edema.

Pulmonary Fibrosis (Option D): Usually displays reticular interstitial markings, honeycomb lung appearance, and shrunken lung fields. These chronic findings contrast with the acute alveolar pattern of pulmonary edema.
